title: Variant infinity
content:
Hi all

I’m currently cutting some characters for a translation of Frege’s  
_Grundgesetze_ and one of them, a variant infinity, has me  
completely baffled. Has anyone seen anything like it before?

[http://miles.shef.ac.uk/~jjg/infinity.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808062040/http:/miles.shef.ac.uk/~jjg/infinity.jpg "http://miles.shef.ac.uk/~jjg/infinity.jpg")

[I tried attaching the image but got “File copy failed: no directory configured,  
or it could not be accessed”]

I’m tempted to think that this was something designed by Frege himself  
and cut by his printer (Hermann Pohl, Jenna, 1893); note the asymmetry  
in the overbar, the uniform width of the bowl strokes. But Frege took  
great care in the typography of the _Grundgesetze_ (and paid for  
its publication himself) so surely this cannot be the case.

Any pointers would be most gratefully received!

 [‹ need font for gravestone](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808062040/http:/typophile.com/node/19169 "Go to previous forum topic") [magazine layout design ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808062040/http:/typophile.com/node/19207 "Go to next forum topic")

comments.content:
[Bump]

Someone must have something to say about this.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808062040im_/http:/typophile.com/files/bizarreinfinity.jpg)

I’d describe this as two below breve’s (U+032E) with a combining double inverted breve (U+0361) above but with no base character I can’t get this to shape in Word using the updated core fonts I’m using.

After trying google, I had a thought could the translation be variable infinity? Because googling Frege variable infinity brings more hits  
 [http://members.cox.net/wehmeier/russell01.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808062040/http:/members.cox.net/wehmeier/russell01.pdf "http://members.cox.net/wehmeier/russell01.pdf")

[http://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/~slr/teach2005/PY5321-9.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808062040/http:/www.st-andrews.ac.uk/~slr/teach2005/PY5321-9.pdf "http://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/~slr/teach2005/PY5321-9.pdf")

All way above my head.  
Or is it an upsidedown picture of a seagull flying low over a still sea?  
Tim

I know enough logic to be dangerous, but I am not familiar with Frege’s notations, especially as originally published.

My undereducated guess is that this is a stylized lowercase \omega with a wide inverted breve above. If I were drawing it, I’d use the same ductus (or lack thereof) as the \union sign. The part below might indeed by a double\union, but if it _does_ mean some kind of infinity, \omega makes more sense as it is often used as an infinity sign. I wouldn’t worry about the asymmetry - if it had real meaning, I doubt it would be done that subtly.

What methodology are you going to use to draw your fonts? If it’s not too many glyphs and you don’t have a strong attachment to doing it all yourself, I might be tempted to pitch in.

Raph

Thanks for the comments.

_If I were drawing it, I’d use the same ductus (or lack thereof) as the \union sign,_

That’s what I’ve done for my first cut of it, but the lower  
and upper parts being in different styles jars a bit to my eye.

_What methodology are you going to use to draw your fonts?_

The book will be set with TeX (what else!) and I’m doing the  
font in metafont. Thanks for the offer of help. but it is  
pretty much done now, I would be interested in comments though,  
sample at

[http://miles.shef.ac.uk/~jjg/sample.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808062040/http:/miles.shef.ac.uk/~jjg/sample.pdf "http://miles.shef.ac.uk/~jjg/sample.pdf")

(900KB). The infinity is on page 4.

Cheers
